comment.author: 24861755@N08
comment.authorname: Christine Rose.., Huge Thanks To All My Flick'r Fr

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: I had seen this one before somewhere, as a child I was a member of na Fianna but we were not nearly as pretentious as these lads.  Stu has a name on the Schafer method - I can't remember the name of what the second lad is doing but it was the method used where the arms were moved vigorously about and pressed into the solar plexus to do the same thing.  The swords were probably more in order in that era, we did not have access to them.

comment.author: 10988810@N06
comment._content: There is a small hillock in Merrion Sq. but the considerable structure on the far left causes confusion. Small mounds like this can be removed and rebuilt quite easily I suppose. The number of windows and chimney pots on the houses might just provide a starting point for investigation.

comment.author: 40089693@N07
comment._content: Great posture on the lad in the center, born leader perhaps!?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Would you have like access to swords, Sean? :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/10988810@N06] Did think of the mound in Merrion Square, but as you say, that's a helluva structure on the left... Don't think there would ever have been something so huge inside the corner railings of Merrion Square. Next time I'm walking through the Square, I'll try to see if the houses/chimney pots behind the mound from that angle look the same.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 10988810@N06
comment._content: I took some shot yesterday in Merrion Sq in an effort to see if the background matches. I notice that the work area where the grounds people keep their tools etc. appears to be roughly where the building on the left is in the above snap. This doesn't add much to the discovery of the actual location I know but it has me perplexed.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/10988810@N06] Snap! I was in there today myself. From that angle, the chimneypots and roofscape are completely hidden by gorgeous mature trees, but from outside, they do look right! So next step in investigation is finding out if there ever was a structure where the grounds keepers are based now... And an obelisk on top of the mound - certainly not there today.

One thing to bear in mind is that it wasn't until the 1970s that Merrion Square was open to the public. Before that it was accessible only to keyholders of the houses around the Square. Need to find out where Countess Markievicz lived in Dublin. How would the respectable denizens of Merrion Square have felt about Fianna Éireann training activities being carried on under their noses? They were also trained in the use of firearms, though hardly in the city centre!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 10988810@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] This other shot (flag message image) could provide fairly strong evidence also counting the number of windows etc.

comment.author: 54708393@N08
comment._content: Looking at this it strikes me that the location might be at the present site of the Garden of Rememberance on Parnell Sq.looking towards Denmark St/Fredrick St. With the tall structure on the left being the Abby Church, of course the mound and obelisk would have been removed for the construction of the Gardens in the 1960s.I worked in that area for several years in the late sixties and it looks very familier.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/54708393@N08] Perfectly plausible, Philip! (Shakes metaphorical fist at Georgian houses for looking so similar at the roofscape). Wonder if we've other photos in our collections from inside or outside the railings, so we can catch ourselves a mound + an obelisk...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I think Philip has it exactly right. Look at the crazy line of chimney pots I've highlighted, and then this streetview. The OS 25" map shows a grassy knoll in this corner.

comment.author: 71822085@N03
comment._content:
Hope its OK to add to an old thread - the "swords" are French model 1874 gras sword bayonets - instantly identifiable by the brass pommel and hooked quillion.  Interesting that they seem to be a regular piece of kit - I wonder did the Fianna import a job lot into Howth?
-Dave

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/71822085@N03] Absolutely ok to add to an old, a new, or anywhere in between thread, Dave! Delighted to receive information at any time...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
